steps: Raw materials of PbO, K2CO3, Nb2O5, and Ta2O5 were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio and ball-milled with zirconia balls in nylon jars for 12 h.
Additional 2 wt% of PbO was introduced for compensating the volatilization of PbO during the sintering process.
After drying at 120 °C, the powders were calcined at 900 °C for 4 h and re-milled for another 6 h.
The dried powders were mixed with polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder and sieved through a screen mesh.
The particles were pressed into pellets with a diameter of 12 mm and thickness around 1.2 mm under uniaxial pressure of 15 MPa.
The green pellets were fired at 500 °C for 2 h for binder burn-out.
All specimens were sintered at 1190–1250 °C for 1 h.
The cooling process was controlled at 3 °C/min till 600 °C to prevent the ceramics from cracking. A natural cooling without quenching is performed below 600 °C.
The optimal sintering temperature was determined to be 1230 °C via analyzing the bulk densities obtained from the Archimedes principle.
For piezoelectric property measurements, the sintered pellets were coated with silver paste on both surfaces and dried at 120 °C for 30 min to solidify the electrodes.
All samples were polarized in silicon oil at 150 °C with a DC electric field up to 4 kV/mm for 30 min.

steps: The raw chemicals of BaCO3, TiO2, HfO2, Fe2O3 were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio, and ball-milled for 12 h with ethyl alcohol as the medium.
The mixture was dried and then calcined at 1250 ℃ for 2 h with a heating rate of 5 ℃/min.
The calcined powder was ball-milled again in ethanol for 12 h, and dried at 90 ℃ for 3 h.
This mixture was pressed into pellets with a diameter of 8 mm using 5 wt% PVA (Poly Vinyl Alcohol) as a binder, and heated at 500 ℃ for 5 h to volatilize the PVA.

steps: All raw materials were dried in an oven at approximately 120°C for 5 hours.
The weighed raw materials were mixed by ball milling for 12 hours with ethanol as a medium.
The dried raw materials were calcined at 850°C for 2 hours to obtain the object composition of NBBT100x ceramics.
The calcined powder was secondly ball milled for another 12 hours to reduce the particle size.
The calcined powder was dried in an oven and granulated by passing through 80 mesh sieve.
Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) aqueous solution (5 wt. %) was added as a binder, and the amount is approximately 10 wt.% of the powder mass.
The green bodies were heated to 800°C for 2 hours to remove the binder.
NBBT100x green bodies were sintered at 1140°C-1180°C for 2 hours.
The polished ceramic disks were heated to 1100°C for 1 hour and then removed directly from the furnace to air for a rapid cooling.

steps: The piezoelectric feedstock was prepared using a binder system consisting of KICET-PZT8 piezoelectric powder, paraffin wax, and ethylene-vinyl-acetate (EVA).
The preform of the 1-3 type composite was fabricated using a ceramic injection molding (CIM) machine (NEX-500, NISSEI Japan) with the prepared feedstock.
The PZT composite preform was sintered at 1250 °C for 2 h.
A polymer (301, EPOTEK) was poured into the sintered preform.
The polymer-poured specimens were cured at 80 °C for 12 h.
The final cured specimens were machined into shapes optimized by simulation.
Room-temperature-curing silver electrodes were applied to the machined specimens.
Polarization was performed by applying an electric field of 2.5 kV/mm for 20 min in a silicone oil bath at 120 °C.

steps: The raw materials were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio of the general formula and mixed by ball-milling with ZrO2 balls in ethanol for 12 hours.
The dried mixtures were then calcined at 850 °C for 2 hours.
The mixtures were subjected to an additional 24-hour ball-milling under the same conditions.

The synthesized CBN-100xTm powders were ground and granulated with a polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) binder, then pressed into discs measuring 12 mm in diameter and 1 mm in thickness under a pressure of 150 MPa.
The PVA was removed by heating at 650 °C.

The green samples were sintered in a muffle furnace. For CaBi2Nb2O9 ceramics, the sintering was done at 1150 °C for 3 hours, while thulium-substituted CBN ceramics were sintered at temperatures ranging from 1100 to 1140 °C for 3 hours.

Textured ceramics were prepared using a two-step sintering method with a spark plasma sintering (SPS) system. Initially, the CBN-100xTm powders were placed into a graphite die with an inner diameter of 10 mm and heated to 990 °C for 3 minutes at a heating rate of 100 °C/min under a constant load of 60 MPa, forming a fully densified block.

This block was then deformed in another graphite die with a larger inner diameter of 20 mm at 1130 °C for 5 minutes under a constant load of 40 MPa. The heating rate for this step remained 100 °C/min.
After sintering, the samples were annealed in a muffle furnace at 1000 °C for 4 hours in air to remove any infiltrated carbon.

steps: Commercial PZT ceramic discs of grade SP-6 were sourced and measured 20 mm in diameter and 2 ± 0.04 mm in thickness.

Both sides of the PZT discs were coated with silver using screen printing with a proprietary silver paste, followed by firing at approximately 800°C in air to achieve a final silver coating thickness of around 25 μm.
The quality of the bond between the screen-printed silver electrodes and PZT discs was assessed using ultrasonic C-scan imaging.
Nickel wear plates, each 2 mm thick, were machined from Ni-200 rods and ground to achieve a planarity of approximately 10 μm and a roughness of about 1 μm.

The Ni wear plate was first coated with silver using a DC sputtering process to a thickness of about 6 μm, followed by heating the coated surface in flowing hydrogen gas at 700 °C for 2 h to facilitate the diffusion of silver into the nickel and establish a solid solution.
An additional silver coating of about 3 μm thickness was applied, bringing the overall thickness of Ag coating on the nickel wear plate to approximately 9 μm.
The PZT discs and nickel wear plates were placed in a vessel with a 10 mm thick plate and a special slot for positioning a sample holder, which was evacuated to a high vacuum of less than -10^-2 Pa.

The vessel was heated up to 700 °C using a split furnace, and a uniaxial press applied a predetermined pressure (up to 40 MPa) on the bonding components while maintaining the vacuum inside the vessel.
Two different bonding temperatures were used: 275 °C (below the Curie temperature, Tc, of PZT) and 400 °C (above Tc). A bonding pressure of 20 MPa was used, and the bonding duration was set to 1 h.
In cases 1 & 2, a 1 μm thick silver coating was applied over the screen-printed silver layer on the PZT disc using DC magnetron sputtering.

In cases 3 & 4, the screen-printed silver coating on the PZT disc was removed, and a ~10 μm silver was applied. After each 3 μm layer of silver was deposited, the disc was heated to 800 °C to ensure adhesion of the silver to the PZT disc.

Initially, a load of approximately 1 MPa was applied to the components, followed by evacuation of the vessel to less than -10^-2 Pa. The furnace was then put on, and once the desired temperature was reached, the final load of 20 MPa was applied.
After maintaining the components under this pressure for 1 h, the furnace was turned off, and the vessel was allowed to cool to room temperature.

The PZT discs that met the quality standards were subjected to thermal cycles between 250 °C and room temperature in air. Each cycle involved heating the PZT disc bonded to the nickel wear plate to 250 °C at a rate of 3 °C per hour, holding at that temperature for 2 h, and then furnace cooling to room temperature.
The d33 values were measured before and after the thermal cycling, and C-scan imaging of the bond was performed at the end of the first and 10th cycles.

For PZT discs bonded at 400 °C, repoling was performed using a DC poling unit. The PZT discs were immersed in dry silicone oil maintained at 150 °C, and a DC potential of 15 kV was applied across the disc for 15 min.

steps: The starting materials were combined in stoichiometric ratios.
Simultaneous differential thermal analysis (DTA) and thermogravimetric (TG) analysis were conducted up to 1300 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.
Based on the thermal analyses data, the samples were first heated at 800 °C for 2 h.
The samples were then heated to 1150 °C for 10 h in pure alumina crucibles under an open atmosphere, followed by slow cooling.
The ceramic discs (1 mm in thickness, 10 mm in diameter) were formed from the obtained powder materials.
The ceramic discs were compacted using uniaxial pressing under a pressure of 250 MPa and 2 wt% of a 5 wt% PVA aqueous solution as a binder.
The samples were heated at 600 °C for 30 min to eliminate the organic additives.
Sintering was conducted at 1400 °C for 4 h.
Silver paste (99.9%) was applied to the discs' surfaces, heated, and fired at 650 °C for 1 h.
The discs were polished on emery paper (1200 grit) to create smooth surfaces.
To form surface electrodes, the discs were fired at 650 °C for 1 h.

steps: The raw powders of (Bi0.5Na0.5)TiO3, BaCO3, TiO2, and MnO2 were weighed according to the chemical formula.
The powders were ball-milled with zirconia balls with a diameter of 1 mm and ethanol at 250 rpm for 16 h.
The mixture was dried at 80 °C.
A 5 wt% polyvinyl butyral binder was added to the dried mixture and passed through a 250 µm mesh.
The mixed powder of about 0.5 g and a SrTiO3 seed crystal was pressed into a disc compact in a die with a diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa.
The SrTiO3 seed crystal was located at the center of the compact, with its 3 mm × 3 mm faces mirror-polished and parallel to the (110) face and parallel to the faces of the compact.
Several compacts were heated at 700 °C for 2 h in the air to remove the binder.
The compacts were then heated at 1200 °C for 24 h in the air for sintering in a box-type electric furnace.
The heating and cooling rates were 150 °C/h.

steps: A certain molar mass of Ta2O5, CH3COOLi·2H2O, and C4H6O6 (C4H6O6 vs. cations = 2:3) were separately dissolved in ethanol.
The solution was mixed with commercial LCO powders and vigorously stirred.
The mixed solution was evaporated and stirred at 80 °C until a sol was formed.
The sol was aged at 120 °C for 10 h to obtain a gel.
The powder was annealed at 500 °C for 12 h and then cooled to room temperature.
For pure LTO samples, the preparation was similar, without adding LCO during the experiment.
The LTO powders were compacted into disk by uniaxial pressing in a stainless-steel die using polyvinyl butyral binder.
The disk was sintered in air at 500 °C for 3 h.

The weighed powder and moderate ethanol were mixed and ball-milled for 12 hours.
The mixture was placed into an oven and dried at 120 °C.
After the powder was completely dried, the powder was calcined at 1250 °C for 5 hours.
The calcined powder was ball-milled again for 12 hours.
The ball-milled powder was pressed into a desired size and shape by a cold isostatic press machine at 30 MPa for 15 minutes.
The sample was kept at a sintering temperature of 1400–1500 °C for 4 hours to obtain a dense ceramic plate.

steps: MgO, Sc2O3, and Nb2O5 were used to synthesize the precursors MgNb2O6 (fabricated at 1000 °C) and ScNbO4 (fabricated at 1150 °C).

MgNb2O6, ScNbO4, TiO2, and PbO powders were selected and weighed in accordance with the stoichiometric proportion and 2 mol% PbO extra was added to make up for the vaporization of PbO during sintering.
Alcohol and the above oxide powders were mixed in a 1:1 ratio by wet-milling for 24 h.
The combined powder was subjected to calcination at 800 − 850 °C for 2 h, the calcined mixture was mixed again for 12 h.
The powder was conglutinated with a solution of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and pressed into tablets under 8 MPa, and then the PVA was burned off at 550 °C for a duration of 2 h.
The ceramic tablets were covered by powders with the same composition to maintain a Pb-rich atmosphere and sintered at 1200 − 1280 °C for 4 h.
The polished samples (cylindrical disks with diameters of 11.40 − 11.54 mm and thickness of 0.74 − 0.90 mm) were coated with sliver electrodes on both sides in preparation for electrical tests.

steps: The raw precursors were added to an Erlenmeyer flask, and then ethanol was added to react for 3 h to obtain polymer solutions.
The solutions were placed in the oven at 120 °C for 10 h and then calcined at 900 °C for 2 h in a muffle furnace to form precursor powders.

The powders were mixed with 2 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as an organic binder (the weight ratio of PVA and powders was 1:120) and formed into disks with a diameter of 20 mm under 20 MPa pressure with a retention time of 150 s.
The disks were embedded in alumina and sintered at 1300 °C for 4 h in air using a heating rate of 5 °C/min.

steps: 0.011 mol Bi(NO3)3 and 0.01 mol Fe(NO3)3·9H2O were weighed and dissolved into 100 mL of deionized water to obtain 0.11 M bismuth nitrate and 0.1 M iron nitrate solutions.
3 mL of 68% nitric acid was added to the bismuth nitrate solution during constant stirring until it was completely dissolved.
The two solutions were mixed and 0.02 mol of triammonium citrate was added as a complexing agent and stirred for 30 min.
The gel of the reaction intermediate was obtained by continuous stirring at 90°C until the water was completely evaporated.
The gel was calcined at 550°C for 2 h to obtain pure phase BFO powder particles.
10 mL of 0.3 M cadmium chloride solution was added to 50 mL of 0.1 M sodium citrate solution and stirred at room temperature for 20 min.
3 mL of concentrated ammonia (28%) and 10 mL of 0.6 M thiourea solution were added sequentially.
The mixed solution was reacted in a water bath at 60°C for 2.5 h.
The precipitate was collected by centrifugation, rinsed with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, and dried in an oven at 60°C to obtain CdS nanosheets.
0.6 g of BFO was weighed into 60 mL of 0.1 M sodium citrate solution, and 1.38 mL of 0.3 M cadmium chloride solution was added according to 10 wt% of BFO, and stirred at room temperature for 3 h.
3.6 mL of concentrated ammonia (28%) and 1.38 mL of 0.9 M thiourea solution were slowly added.
The reaction was carried out at 60°C in a water bath for 2.5 h.
The precipitate was collected, rinsed with deionized water and anhydrous ethanol, and dried in an oven at 60°C to obtain 10% CdS/BiFeO3 (BC10) samples.
Cadmium chloride solution and thiourea solution could be further increased in stoichiometric ratios to obtain 20% CdS/BiFeO3 (BC20) and 30% CdS/BiFeO3 (BC30).

steps: Weighing precise amounts of Sc2O3, TiO2, ZnO, Bi2O3, and Pb3O4 according to the stoichiometric ratio with an excess of 1 mol% for both Bi2O3 and Pb3O4.
Subjecting the resulting powders to ball milling in alcohol for 12 h.
Drying the milled powders.
Calcining the dried powders at 750 °C for 4 h to obtain pure BZT-BS-PT ceramic powders.
Performing two rounds of milling and drying.
Carrying out a granulation process by adding 5 wt% PVA to the powder mixture.
Pressing the ceramic green body under a uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa.
Heat treating the pressed green body at 600 °C for 4 h to remove any remaining adhesive material.
Subjecting the ceramic body to a buried firing process at 1000 °C for 3 h to achieve fully densified BZT-BS-PT ceramics.

steps: The raw materials were mixed with alcohol and ball milled for 24 hours.
The calcined powder was obtained by heating at 1300 °C for 3 hours.
BCZT powders for vat photopolymerization were produced by a second stage of ball milling using a range of time periods (1 h, 2 h, 4 h, 12 h).

The BCZT ceramic slurry was prepared by mixing the ceramic powder with light-sensitive oligomers, a diluent, photo-initiator, and dispersant (0.5 wt% of the ceramic powder) using a vacuum mixer for 300 s at 2500 rpm.
The ceramic slurry was poured into the VPP printer to produce the ceramic green body; the layer thickness was set to 30 μm.
Debinding of the resulting ceramic green body was completed in a tube furnace at 425 °C for 4 h, with varying temperature ramp rates of 0.1 °C min^-1, 0.2 °C min^-1, and 0.3 °C min^-1.
During the sintering process, the sample was kept at 550 °C for 2 h to remove any residual carbon.

The BCZT ceramic scaffold structure was obtained by heating at 3 °C min^-1 to the sintering temperature (1380 °C, 1400 °C, 1420 °C, 1440 °C) and furnace cooling to room temperature after holding for 3 h.
The sintered BCZT ceramics were directly polarized at 15 kV for 1 h using a corona poling technique.
A polyethylene glycol terephthalate (PET) film, covered with indium tin oxide (ITO), was glued to both sides of the BCZT scaffold with a silver glue.
The resulting piezoelectric sensor was obtained after curing for 12 h at room temperature.

steps: High purity (>99.9 %) chemical powders of Na2CO3, Bi2O3, TiO2, BaCO3, and ZrO2 were weighted stoichiometrically.
The powders were ball milled for 24 hours at 300 rpm with alumina balls using acetone as mixing media.
The mixed powders were dried in an oven.
The dried powders were calcined at 900°C for 3 hrs.
Disc-shaped pellets were prepared using ~13 mm diameter under a uniaxial pressure of 200 MPa.

steps: 0.1 M concentration is prepared by dissolving Lead (II) acetate in glacial acetic acid and stoichiometric concentration of Zirconium (IV) n-butoxide and Titanium (IV) n-butoxide is separately added with the lead precursor and stirred.
The appropriate amount of distilled water and ethylene glycol are added and stirred for 30 mins.
10 wt% of polyvinyl pyrrolidone is added and stirred for another 1 hr.
The solution is filtered using Whatman filter paper prior to deposition.
The buffer layers (TiO, LNO, LNO/TiO) are prepared by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s and subsequently annealed at 650 °C for 30 mins.
The PZT film is deposited by spin coating at 4000 rpm for 30 s and it undergoes two step annealing process i.e., 400 °C for 2 mins and 650 °C for 2 mins.
All the films undergo 12 cycles to achieve the desired thickness of ~1000 nm and subsequently annealed at 650 °C for 30 mins in an open-air atmosphere furnace.

steps: The nominal composition 1.0 mol% Mn-doped 0.28Pb(In1/2Nb1/2)O3-0.42Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.30PbTiO3 single crystal was grown along [001] by the modified Bridgman method.
The single crystal was cut into 6 × 6 × 0.38 mm³ unit sheets.
To ensure the uniformity of PSAs, the unit sheets were extracted from the same horizontal cross-section of the single crystal boule.
The unit sheets were annealed at 600 °C for 4 hours and cleaned.
Ultrathin conductive gold layers with a thickness of 100 nm were deposited on the surface of unit sheets by a sputtering method.
To create an electrically parallel structure, 0.5 mm wide insulating margins were left on alternating upper and lower surfaces during the electrode plating process.

The unit sheets underwent direct current polarization (DCP) along the [001] direction, with a condition of 135 °C, 1 kV/mm, and 10 minutes, using a CS2674 AX voltage tester in a thermostatic oil bath.
15 layers of unit sheets were bonded using E-44(6101) epoxy in an electrical parallel and mechanical series configuration.
Zirconia ceramic sheets with a thickness of 0.5 mm were affixed to the top and bottom surfaces to enhance rigidity.
The stacked samples were subjected to a 5 MPa pressure applied longitudinally using an isostatic press.
The samples were statically cured for 48 hours.
PSAs were finished with dimensions of 6 × 6 × 6.7 mm³.

steps: High-purity MgO and Nb2O5 powders were mixed and calcined at 1100°C for 5 hours to produce the precursor columbite.

The PMN-PT powders were pressed into 13 mm-diameter cylinders by uniaxial dry pressing.

steps: La2O3 and Nb2O5 mixed at a mass ratio of 3:2 were ball-milled in ethanol for 12 hours, then sieved to prepare the LN additive.

The mixtures were dried in an oven at 80 °C for 1–2 hours and calcined at 820 °C for 2 hours.
The synthesized powders were weighted based on the PT–PZ–BLZT–xLN formula and subjected to secondary ball milling, drying, and sieving processes.
The granulated powders were pressed into 12 mm thick sheets under the granulation of 5% polyvinyl alcohol.
The sheets were sintered at 600 °C for 4 hours to remove the binder, followed by sintering at 1230 °C for 2 hours to synthesize the ceramic samples.

steps: The weighed powder was ground with zirconia balls in ethanol for 24 h.

The silver-plated ceramic samples were then polarised in silicone oil at 110 °C for 15 min using a DC field of 5 kV/cm.

steps: The [001]-oriented BTO template powders were synthesized from Bi2O3 and TiO2 using the molten salt method, with an equal molar ratio of NaCl and KCl in a 1:1 wt ratio.
The template powder was then sintered at 1100 °C for 1 h.
The BTO matrix powders were prepared by a solid-state reaction, with the Bi2O3 and TiO2 powders weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
The raw materials were then calcined at 700 °C for 2 h.
To meet the requirements of the TGG method, the calcined powder was ball milled for 48h–72h to achieve a small particle size.
The template and matrix powders were mixed by ball milling at a mixing speed of ~60 rpm, using xylene and ethanol as solvents.
To the solution, 5 vol% of BTO template was added to the solution and stirred for 1 h to ensure homogenization.
Tape casting was performed with a blade gap of 210 μm.
After drying at room temperature for 8–10h, the tapes were cut into 10 × 10 mm squares and laminated under a pressure of 75 MPa for 1–3h.
The organics were burned off at 600 °C for 3h.
To assess the texture evolution of the BTO ceramics, the green bodies were heated in a tube furnace from 650 °C to 1000 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min.
The green bodies were then sintered in an oxygen atmosphere at 950 °C for 0–6 h to measure their electrical properties.

steps: The powders were ground using a planetary ball mill for 12 h, and anhydrous ethanol was used as the solvent.

0.2 wt% MnO2 was added to the calcined powders.
The calcined powders were ground using the planetary ball mill for 12 h and dried again.
A 6 wt% polyvinyl alcohol binder (PVA) was added to the calcined powders, and the powders were pressed into discs under a pressure of 6–8 MPa.
The discs were heated at 600 °C for 2 h to remove the PVA.
The pellets were sintered at 950 °C-1050 °C for 2.5 h in the air.

steps: Mixing the precursors in their respective stoichiometric ratios in propan-2-ol and acetic acid as solvents, with pentane-2,4-dione as the polymerizing agent.
Stirring the mixture at room temperature at 700 rpm.
Allowing the final 0.3 M solution to polymerize for seven days.
Depositing each thin-film sample consisting of 6 layers of BNKT-20-3M on a commercial Pt/Ti/SiO2/Si substrate via spin-coating.
Spinning each layer at 500 rpm for 10 s and then at 4000 rpm for 30 s.
Applying a series of heat treatments including evaporation at 200 °C, pyrolysis at 500 °C, and annealing at 750 °C, each for 5 min.
Repeating the above sequence 6 times to achieve a thin-film sample approximately 220 nm thick.
For comparison, some thin-film samples were further heat-treated in a nitrogen (N2) atmosphere at 1 atm, 750 °C for 30 min after the cooling procedure for defect passivation.
Depositing circular Pt top electrodes with an area of 0.283 mm² on the thin-film sample by RF magnetron sputtering in argon plasma.

steps: The 0.15PSN-0.57PMN-0.28PT matrix powder, averaging 300 nm in particle size, was synthesized using the traditional solid state reaction method.
Pure perovskite matrix powder was produced by sintering the mixed raw materials at 750 °C for 2 h.
The plate-like BT templates with [001] orientation were synthesized by the topochemical transformation technique.
The embryo strips were sliced, stacked, and compressed for 30 min at 70 °C with 10 MPa of pressure.
The organic matters were discharged by sintering at 550 °C for 2 h.
Samples were subjected to isostatic pressing at a pressure of 200 MPa for a duration of 1 min.

article_metadata.title: Microstructure and electric properties in PSN-PMN-PT textured ceramics by template grain growth technology

steps: The mixture of raw materials was ball-milled using zirconia balls (Φ = 1 mm, 3 mm, 5 mm, and 10 mm) for 24 h and dried at 90°C.
The milled PNN-PZT powders were calcined at 850°C for 4 h (heating rate: 5°C/min).
0.2 wt% of Li2CO3 was added to the calcined 0.5Pb(Ni1/3Nb2/3)O3-0.16PbZrO3-0.34PbTiO3 powder as a sintering aid.
The mixture was subsequently ball-milled for 48 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 1 mm, 3 mm, 5 mm, and 10 mm) and dried at 90°C.

Ethyl alcohol, toluene, dibutyl phthalate, polyvinyl butyral, and dispersant were mixed with PNNZT powders at an optimized ratio and ball-milled for 24 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm, and 15 mm).
After ball milling, the PNNZT slurry was separated from the zirconia balls using a mesh fabric, and any remaining air bubbles were removed using a vacuum chamber for 15 min.
An aging process followed for 2 h at 15 rpm to stabilize the slurry.
BT-template-free thick sheets were prepared via tape casting at a casting speed of 1 m/min with a blade gap of 85 μm.
The resulting PNNZT sheets had a thickness of 17 μm.

Ethyl alcohol, toluene, dibutyl phthalate, polyvinyl butyral, and dispersant were mixed with PNNZT powders at an optimized ratio and ball-milled for 24 h with zirconia balls (Φ = 3 mm, 5 mm, 10 mm, and 15 mm).
After ball milling, the PNNZT slurry was separated from the zirconia balls using a mesh fabric.
BT templates were dispersed in a small amount of ethanol using a sonicator for 5 min and then added to the separated PNNZT slurry.
Any remaining air bubbles in the slurry were removed using a vacuum chamber for 15 min.
The slurry was then aged for 2 h at 15 rpm to stabilize it.
BT-included thin sheets were prepared via tape casting at a casting speed of 1 m/min with a blade gap of 8 μm.
The resulting PNNZT-BT sheets had a thickness of 5 μm.
The obtained PNNZT and PNNZT-BT sheets were alternately laminated, one by one, using a lamination machine under 10 MPa of pressure and at a temperature of 60°C.
The laminated sheets were then subjected to a warm isostatic pressing (WIP) process to achieve denser laminates, by applying 25 MPa of pressure at 65°C for 20 min.
After the WIP process, the PNNZT/PNNZT-BT laminates were cut into 10 mm × 10 mm pieces using a blade cutter.
To burn out the organic components in the PNNZT/PNNZT-BT laminates, the cut pieces were fired at 300°C and 600°C for 5 h at each temperature, with a heating rate of 1°C/min.

Thereafter, the fired PNNZT/PNNZT-BT laminates were pressed using a cold isostatic press (CIP) machine for 1 min under 200 MPa at room temperature to compensate for the volumetric loss of organic components.
The CIP-treated specimens were then sintered at various temperatures ranging from 900°C to 1025°C, in 25°C intervals, for 15 h under an O2 atmosphere.
During sintering, the flow rate and heating rate were maintained at 1 L/min and 1°C/min, respectively.
After sintering, Ag paste was applied to both sides of the sintered body and fired at 700°C for 10 min.
Finally, poling was conducted at 3.5 kV/mm for 20 min at room temperature in silicone oil.

The mixture was mixed on a horizontal rolling ball mill at a rotating speed of 410 r/min for 24 h and then dried.
The obtained mixture was sieved by a 100-mesh sifter and then calcined at 750 °C for 6 h.

steps: Yb2O3, MgO and Nb2O5 were used to synthesize fine YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors.
Stoichiometric PbO, TiO2, MnO2, YbNbO4 and MgNb2O6 precursors were ball-milled in ethanol with ZrO2 media.
The mixture was calcined at 775 °C for 2h followed by ball milling again.
BaTiO3 (BT) platelets prepared by topochemical microcrystal conversion were used as templates.
3 vol% BT templates were added into the slurry.
After binders burning out, green samples were cold isostatic pressed at 200 MPa.
Textured ceramics were sintered between 1150 and 1200 °C for 6h.
For comparison, randomly oriented Mn-doped PYN-PMN-PT ceramics were synthesized by the same procedure without addition of BT templates.

article_metadata.title: Synergetic enhancement in the piezoelectric coefficient and electromechanical factor in PYN-PMN-PT ceramics via texture engineering

steps: Weighed raw materials were ball-milled for 24 h in ethanol using zirconia balls with 3 mm of diameter.
Dried and calcined powders at 900 °C for 4 h.
Before the second milling process, 1 mol% BE^{3+} was added to both pre-synthesized undoped and 1 mol% MnE^{3+} doped BNT-6BT.
Uniaxially pressed at 100 MPa pressure disc samples with a diameter of 12 mm were shaped using the screened powders (<90 μm) mixed with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder.
Pre-shaped specimens were re-pressed via a cold isostatic press (CIP) at 150 MPa.
PVA binder was burnt out at 600 °C for 4 h in the furnace set to a 1 °C/min heating rate.
A sintering process at 1150 °C was performed for 12 h in air.

steps: The substrate material (pure Mg) was mechanically ground with SiC paper up to 1000 grit, ultrasonically cleaned in ethyl alcohol, and then dried in cold air.
Mg plates were used as the anode, and a stainless steel chamber was used as the cathode and reactor.
The pulse reverse power provided a constant current of 2 A/dm² for 660 s under the frequency of 500 Hz and a duty cycle of 15%.
The electrolyte was prepared based on silicate salt (20 g/L Na2SiO3 + 4 g/L KF + 2 g/L NaOH).
The BaTiO3 content in the PEO coating is controlled by the concentration of BaTiO3 powder added to the electrolyte (2 g/L for PEO-BTO2 and 5 g/L for PEO-BTO5).
The solution was cooled down using a water-cooling system at 30 ± 5 °C during the coating process.
After PEO treatment, the samples were rinsed in distilled water and dried in warm air.

steps: The geometry structure of pristine MoS2 unit cell was relaxed to ensure the reliability of subsequent results.
A 4 × 4 MoS2 supercell was constructed to screen which site is favorable for TM (Ni, Pd, Pt, Ir) adsorption.
TMs were adsorbed on 4 × 4, 3 × 3, and 2 × 2 MoS2 supercells to consider the influence of concentration.
The adsorption energies (E_ad) were calculated to characterize the thermodynamic stability of TMs adsorbed on MoS2.
AIMD simulations were carried out to understand the stability of the composed structures at room temperature.
The band structures of TM@MoS2 were examined to verify the semiconducting property.
The piezoelectric coefficients e_ij and d_ij were calculated to evaluate the piezoelectric properties of TM@MoS2.

Thin films (0.8–1 µm thickness, depending on filler concentration) were fabricated by spin-coating onto glass substrates pre-coated with aluminum electrodes.
A metal-insulator-metal (MIM) structure was formed by depositing additional aluminum electrodes onto the spin-coated films.
Samples were annealed at 100°C to optimize crystallinity.
Bulk samples for piezoelectric measurements were prepared by solution casting method (thickness of 30 µm).

steps: Dissolve 1.74 g of PVDF in 20 ml of N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) and maintain the solution temperature at 60 °C.
Add 10, 20, 30, 40, and 50 wt.% of BCT3 filler to the solution after four hours of mixing of PVDF in DMF.
Stir the solution by setting 500 rpm on the hot plate for an additional four hours.
Cast the solution in a cleaned petri dish and anneal in an oven at 100 °C for 5 h.
Peel off the obtained films from the glass petri dish, cut into square pieces, and hot press at 100 °C by applying 125 kg/cm² pressure.

steps: Raw materials were weighed according to the chemical formula and ball-milled for 24 h.
The powder was pre-fired in a muffle furnace held at 780 °C for 4 h at a heating rate of 2 °C/min.
8 wt% of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) was added as a binder, and a small amount of the powder was pressed into 8 mm diameter disks at a uniaxial pressure of 12 MPa.
These disks were sintered at a ramp rate of 2 °C/min for 3 h at 600 °C to remove the PVA and at 1000 °C for 6 h to obtain ceramic wafers.
Finally, the ceramic discs with double-sided silver electrodes were polarized by placing them in silicon oil at 120 °C and holding them at a DC field of 5 kV/cm for 20 min.

steps: The precursors were ball milled with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 r/min after weighting according to the stoichiometry ratio.
The powders were dried in an oven.
The powders were calcined at 890 °C for 6 h.
The powders were ball-milled again for 12 h.
The powder mixtures were dried and sieved.
The powder mixtures were pressed into pellets with a diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa using a cold isostatic press.
The temperature was raised to 1190 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and then rapidly cooled down to 1090 °C and dwelled for 3–15 h before naturally cooled down.

steps: Powders were mixed and then calcined at temperatures ranging from 700 to 875 °C for 5 h.
Calcined powders were re-milled for 24 h at 250 rpm using a planetary ball mill with ethanol and yttrium stabilized zirconia balls.
Cold sintering-assisted (CSA) experiments were done using an SPS machine in vacuum. A force of 45 kN (400 MPa) was applied over 40 min while maintaining a temperature increase of 5 °C/min to 200 °C.
A thermal post-treatment at 850 °C for 25 min was done with a lower pressure of 245 MPa and a heating and cooling rate of 10 °C/min.
Samples were re-oxidized for 6 h at 850 °C in oxygen to equilibrate the point defects.

steps: Weighed materials and ethanol are poured into a jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
Dried powders are calcined at 850 °C for 6 h.
Raw powders are mixed according to the proportion of the corresponding components, and ethanol is poured into a jar and ball milled for 24 h with ZrO2 balls.
Dried mixed powders are granulated into a floc with 8 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder.
Granulated powders are pressed into disks (1 mm in thickness and 10 mm in diameter) under a pressure of 10 MPa.
PVA is removed, and the disks are buried in the calcined powders and sintered at 1150 °C for 3 h in an air atmosphere.
The heating rate of the sintering process from RT (room temperature) to 1000 °C is 5 °C/min, and 3 °C/min beyond 1000 °C.
Samples with silver electrodes are processed at 600 °C for 10 min.

steps: High-purity oxides were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
The powders were ball-milled in an ethanol medium with zirconia balls for 24 h.
After drying in the oven, the mixture was calcined at 850 °C for 3 h.
The calcined powder underwent an additional 12 h ball milling process in ethanol, followed by drying and granulating by adding 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol.
Upon completion of the sieving process through an 80-mesh screen, uniform powder particles were obtained.
Samples were crafted by uniaxially dry pressing powder mixtures, each with a diameter of 10 mm and a thickness of 1.5 mm.
They underwent sintering at a rate of 3 °C/min, reaching temperatures between 1120 and 1200 °C for a duration of 2 h in an ambient air atmosphere, after the removal of the binder at 550 °C.

steps: High purity K2CO3, Na2CO3, Nb2O5, Sb2O3, CaCO3, ZrO2, Ag2O, and Bi2O3 powders were weighted according to the stoichiometric ratio and mixed by ball-milling in anhydrous ethanol for 24 h.
The mixture was calcined at 850 °C for 5 h to form the main perovskite structure.
The slurry was prepared by mixing the KNNS-(0.04-x)CZ-xBAZ matrix and NaNbO3 (NN) templates in ethanol/toluene co-solvent with polyvinyl butyral (PVB) binder and MnO2 sintering aid.
The uniform slurry was tape casted to green tapes using a doctor blade with a thickness of 30–50 μm.
After drying, the green tapes were cut, stacked, and uniaxially pressed under a pressure of 15 MPa at 70 °C for 20 min.
The organic binder was removed at 600 °C.
The samples were heated to 1190 °C, and then rapidly cooled to 1090 °C and dwelled for 10 h.

steps: High-purity raw materials were weighed and once ball milled with ethyl alcohol for 12 h at 300 rpm according to the stoichiometry ratio.
After drying, the powders were divided into 4 batches, which were calcined at 800, 850, 900, and 950 °C, respectively.
A part of the powders was pressed into compacts with a diameter of 10 mm at 200 MPa using a cold isostatic press (designated as group A).
The residual powders were subjected to another ball-milling for 24 h (designated as group B) and pressed into pellets under the same conditions.

All pellets were sintered by a two-step sintering (TSS) technique, while the temperature was rapidly raised to 1190 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, and then rapidly cooled down to 1090 °C and dwelled for 5 h before naturally cooled down.

steps: The starting materials were mixed in stoichiometric ratios and subjected to ball milling in ethanol at 400 rpm for 12 h.
The mixture underwent drying and then fired at 1200 °C for a duration of 2 h.
After calcination, the material was thoroughly blended with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) and compacted into discs measuring 15 mm in across and 1 mm in thickness by applying a pressure of 10 MPa.
The molded ceramics were placed in a muffle furnace, ramped to 650 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min, and held for 2 h to eliminate PVA.
It was followed by heating to 1400 °C at 5 °C/min and sintering in the air for 3 h to obtain the B1-x S x TZ piezoelectric ceramics.
For electrical characterization, the ceramic surfaces were first uniformly coated with silver paste on both sides using a screen and then heated at 600 °C for half 1 h to cure the paste.
Ultimately, the ceramics were immersed in a silicone oil bath at 40 °C and subjected to polarization with a direct-current (DC) field of 30 kV/cm for 20 min.

steps: The carbonates were dried in an oven at 120 °C for more than 2 h before use.

The calcined powders were milled for 12 h and then pressed into disks with 12.7 mm in diameter using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as a binder.
The green compacts were first fired at 600 °C to remove the PVA binder.
The green compacts were then sintered in ambient atmosphere at a temperature in the range of 1000 °C–1020 °C for 2 h.

The final solution was stirred and mixed for 1 h under continuous heating at 80 °C.

The BCST powder was calcined at 1000 °C for 4 h in a muffle furnace.
The calcined powder was ground in a mortar pestle with 5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) solution until a fine powder was obtained.

steps: Sodium acetate, strontium acetate, bismuth acetate, and barium acetate were weighed in turn according to the stoichiometric ratio by an analytical balance and added to the solvents.
12 mol% excess sodium acetate and 2 mol% excess bismuth acetate were used to compensate for the possible evaporation of sodium and bismuth during high-temperature annealing.
The precursor solution of BNT-ST-100xBT solution was obtained after stirring the mixture at 80°C for one hour.
A solution concentration of 0.4 mol/L was achieved by adjusting the solvent content.
BNT-ST-100xBT solution was deposited on pretreated Pt/TiO2/SiO2/Si substrates by a spin coating method.

The solution was dropped onto the substrate, followed by rotating the substrate at 1500 r/min for 10 s and then 3000 r/min for 40 s to make the precursor solution cover the substrate surface uniformly and completely.
The deposited film was placed in a rapid thermal treatment (RTP) furnace for heat treatment.
Two pyrolysis processes were taken out, at 150°C for 3 min to evaporate the solvent and then at 410°C for 10 min to remove organic components.
The annealing process was taken out at 725°C for 3 min for crystallization.
The deposition and heating procedures were repeated 6 times to prepare BNT-ST-100xBT thin films with the designed thickness.
Au electrodes with a diameter of 0.3 mm were prepared onto the surface of thin films by DC sputtering.

steps: The raw materials were precisely weighed on the basis of the stoichiometric ratio.
All the materials were mixed in deionized water (H2O) and grounded for 6 h by ball-milling. The ratio of materials to balls to water is 1:2:1.
After ball milling, the powder was pressed into blocks and calcined at 850 °C for 2 hours.
The calcined powder was then ball-milled for 12 hours again to obtain uniform PMS-PZT powder.
Dried powder combined with binders PVA (polyvinyl alcohol) was pressed into pellets of a diameter of 20 mm and a thickness of 1.4 mm at a pressure of 7 MPa.
The green bodies were heated at 550 °C for 3 h to remove the PVA.
Then all the green bodies were sintered at 1250 °C for 2 h in a sealed alumina crucible with the same composition powder in the surface of the disks to minimize the evaporation of PbO.
After cooling down, the sintered ceramics were ground into a thickness of 1 mm.
Silver electrodes were fired on the top and bottom surfaces of the ceramics at 720 °C for 20 min.
Then all the ceramics were poled in silicon oil at 130 °C for 40 minutes under an DC electric field of 35 kV/mm.
The polarized ceramics were aged for at least 24 hours at room temperature before testing its piezoelectric properties.

The second calcination cycle was conducted at 900°C for 4 h.
The calcined powder was then re-milled for 24 h, and thermally treated again in an additional two-stage calcination process at 950°C for 4 h, followed by calcination at 1000°C for 2 h.
The obtained powder was then milled again for 4 h to homogeneously reduce the particle size.
The powder was mixed with a binder (5 wt% polyvinyl alcohol) in a mortar and then uniaxial cold-pressed into pellets with a diameter of 12 mm.
The pellets were covered with powder of the same composition and sintered at 1100°C for 2 h in sealed alumina crucibles.

steps: Precursors were dried for a minimum of 12 hours in a 120 °C drying oven.
Ball milling was conducted in 100 % ethanol with a 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 3 h at 125 rpm.
The resulting slurry was dried using a rotary evaporator, ground with an agate mortar and pestle, and sieved with a 250 μm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Three individual calcination pellets with a nominal weight of 3.0 g and a diameter of 25 mm were uniaxially pressed under 5 MPa in a stainless-steel die.
Calcination took place in a muffle furnace at 801.5 °C for 4 hours with a heating rate of 3 °C/min and a cooling rate of approximately 4 °C/min.
Following calcination, pellets were milled in 100 % ethanol with a 250 mL ZrO2 milling jar and 5 mm ZrO2 media for 30 minutes at 125 rpm.
The resulting slurry was dried using a rotary evaporator, ground with an agate mortar and pestle, and sieved with a 150 μm mesh stainless steel sieve.
Approximately 24 sintering pellets with a nominal weight of 0.30 g and a diameter of 10 mm were uniaxially pressed under 30 MPa in a stainless-steel die.
Pellets were isostatically pressed under 200 MPa with a dwell time of one minute.
Pellets were sintered in a partially closed alumina crucible in a triangular configuration with sacrificial powder on both the bottom of the crucible and the surface of each pellet.
Sintering took place in a muffle furnace at 1103.5 °C for 2 hours with a heating rate of 5 °C/min and a cooling rate of approximately 4 °C/min.
Sintered pellets were prepared to a 1 μm surface finish (silicon carbide paper to 5 μm, polycrystalline diamond paste to 1 μm) prior to SEM/EDX analysis.
Some pellets were thermally etched (1037.5 °C for 7 minutes; heating rate 5 °C/min) to increase grain boundary contrast.
All SEM/EDX specimens were carbon coated (approximately 20 nm thickness) prior to imaging with SEM/EDX.

steps: The powders were precisely weighed according to the stoichiometric ratios and then transferred to a nylon tube for 12 h of ball milling in an alcohol dispersing medium.

steps: Prepare 12 wt% P(VDF-TrFE) 80/20 solution in methyl ether ketone (MEK).
Use electrospinning equipped with a grounded rolling collector to prepare nonwoven ES fiber mats of P(VDF-TrFE) 80/20.
Perform first thermal annealing (1A) by holding the ES fiber mat isothermally at 140 °C for various times (10, 60, 180, 360, 720, 1440, and 2880 min).
Perform second thermal annealing (2A) for ES1A-2880 min below Curie temperature (TC) with a fixed isothermal time of 1 day at temperatures of 110, 115, 125, and 130 °C.
Apply corona-charging to achieve permanent remanent polarization (Pr0) for piezoelectricity.

steps: Calcining barium carbonate, zirconium dioxide, and titanium dioxide at 1200 °C for 2 h to form BZT powder.
Pressing BZT powder into a disc shape with a diameter of ~15 mm and a thickness of ~1.5 mm at a pressure of ~85 MPa.
Sintering BZT discs at 1450 °C for 2 h.
Poling BZT discs (dimension ~12 mm and thickness ~1.5 mm) using an electric field of 1.5 kV/mm at 50 °C for 30 min in a silicone oil chamber.
Cutting poled BZT ceramic using a diamond saw in a parallel direction along the polarization axis.
Mixing Portland cement powder, water, epoxy resin, and hardener to form the matrix phase with a water to cement ratio of 0.35 and a volume ratio of epoxy resin and hardener of 7.5.
Filling the cut areas of the BZT ceramic with the matrix mixture.
Curing the samples in a controlled chamber at 60 °C for 5 days at 98 %RH.

steps: Sc2O3 and Nb2O5 powders were wet-mixed via ball milling for 12 h.
The mixture was calcined at 1050 °C for 6 h to obtain the precursor ScNbO4.
The precursors were mixed with PbO, ZrO2, TiO2, MnO2, and Sb2O3.
The mixture was calcined at 850 °C for 2 h to achieve the desired composition of PZT-PMS-PSN.
The resultant powder was crushed for 8 h and then dried.
The fine powder was mixed with the PVA binder at a mass concentration of 7 % and pressed to form Φ10mm pellets at a pressure of 150 MPa.
The binder was cremated at 800 °C for 2 h.
The PZT-PMS-PSN samples were sintered at 1180 °C for 2 h.
The sintered pellets were polished to reach about 0.5 mm.
Both sides of the sample were coated with silver paste and fired at 800 °C for 10 min.

steps: Raw materials were accurately weighed according to a composition of (1-x) (Ba0.95Ca0.05) (Ti0.89Sn0.11)O3-xBiFeO3 (BCTSO-xBFO, x = 0, 0.1, 0.5, 0.9 mol%) and milled with ethanol for 16 h.
The powders were dried at 100 °C.
The dried powders were calcined at 1150 °C for 3 h.
The calcined powders were re-milled with ethanol for 16 h.
The re-milled powders were pressed into disks of 9 mm in diameter using 3% PVA solution as a binder.
The disks were fired at 600 °C for 2 h.
The fired disks were sintered at 1400 °C for 3 h.
The sintered ceramics were polished and coated with silver paste on the top and bottom surfaces and fired at 800 °C for 30 min to obtain an electrode.
The coated ceramics were poled at 50 kV/cm DC field for 30 min at room temperature in a silicone oil bath.

steps: Stoichiometric ratios of high-purity precursors were mixed.
The mixture was ground in a mortar and pestle for 2 h.
The mixture was milled for 4 h in an ethanol solution with zirconia balls in a low-energy ball mill.
The resulting solutions were dried and the obtained lumps were pulverized.
The pulverized material was calcined for 4 h at 1200 °C in air ambient.
The resulting granulated powders were reground and molded into disk-shaped pellets (1 mm thick and 10 mm in diameter) with the addition of 1 wt % polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) as an organic binder.
The pellets were heated for 1 h at 650 °C at a rate of 1 °C per minute to burn off the PVA binder.
The binder-free pellets underwent simultaneous sintering for 4 h at 1400 °C in air.

steps: A total of 1 g colemanite, 80 mg Fe2O3, 500 mg BaCO3, and 500 mg TiO2 were mixed.
The mixture was subjected to ball milling for 15 h at a rotational speed of 300 rpm.
Following the ball-milling process, 2 mL of 13.8 M ammonia solution was added to the mixture, which was then ball-milled for an additional 3 min at the same rotational speed.
The resulting mixture was transferred onto a silicon carbide plate (3 cm × 2 cm).
The ammonia solution was evaporated by heating the plate on a hot plate set to 150 °C.
Subsequently, the SiC plate with the residual mixture was placed into a tubular furnace (Protherm, Furnaces PTF 14/50/450).
The furnace temperature was gradually increased to 1300 °C and maintained for 3 h under a continuous flow of NH3 gas.
Upon completion of the reaction, the NH3 gas flow was stopped at 975 °C, and the furnace was allowed to cool to room temperature.

steps: The raw materials were weighed according to BTN-100xCe nominal composition and then ball mixed for 24 h with anhydrous ethanol and zirconia balls medium.
After separating the balls, the mixed slurries were dried and calcined at 800 °C for 3 h.
The calcined powders were ball milled for 24 h again.
The dried powders were granulated by polyvinyl alcohol solution (PVA, 5 wt%) as adhesive and pressed into green pellets of 13 mm diameter and about 1.0 mm thick under a pressure of 120 ± 10 MPa.
The green pellets were fired at 650 °C for 3 h to burn off the PVA.
The pellets were then sintered at 1065 °C–1105 °C for 3 h in air with 5 °C/min followed by furnace-cooling to ambient temperature.

steps: Barium carbonate (BaCO3), calcium carbonate (CaCO3), zirconium oxide (ZrO2), and titanium oxide (TiO2) were weighed according to the stoichiometric ratio.
The raw materials were mixed with ethanol and ball-milled for 24 h.
The ethanol-ceramic slurry was dried in an oven and ground into a powder.
The powder was calcined at 1250 °C for 3 h with a heating ramping rate of 5 °C/min.
The calcined powders were ground and sieved using a mesh with a size of 63 µm.
For dense BCZT ceramics: The BCZT powders were mixed with poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) and uni-axially cold-compacted at a pressure of 80 MPa to form the green body.
The green body was heated to 500 °C for 2 h using a ramp rate of 1 °C/min to burn out the organic agents.
The green body was then sintered at 1400 °C for 10 h with a ramp rate of 5 °C/min.
For porous BCZT ceramics: The BCZT powders were ball milled for 24 h with deionized water, PVA, and ammonium polyacrylate to form a slurry with a solid loading level of ~20 vol%.
The slurry was poured into a cylindrical mold with PDMS on the sides and high thermal conductivity metal on the bottom.
The slurry was unidirectionally frozen at -80 °C, and the ice was removed by freeze drying to form a porous BCZT green body.
The green bodies formed by freeze-casting were sintered at the same conditions as the dense BCZT.
